Let \[f(x) = \left\{
\begin{array}{cl} ax+3, &\text{ if }x>2, \\
x-5 &\text{ if } -2 \le x \le 2, \\
2x-b &\text{ if } x <-2.
\end{array}
\right.\]Find $a+b$ if the piecewise function is continuous (which means that its graph can be drawn without lifting your pencil from the paper).
inference:
Since the function is continuous at $x=\pm2$, we have to solve the equations
$$a\cdot2+3=2\cdot2-b \qquad \text{ and } \qquad 2\cdot(-2)-b=(-2)-5$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad 2a+3=4-b \qquad \text{ and } \qquad -4-b=-7$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad 2a+3=4-b \qquad \text{ and } \qquad b=-3$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad 2a+3=7 \qquad \text{ and } \qquad b=-3$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad 2a=4 \qquad \text{ and } \qquad b=-3$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad a=2 \qquad \text{ and } \qquad b=-3$$

$$\Rightarrow \qquad a+b=2+(-3)=-1$$

**Final Answer: $\boxed{-1}$. I hope it is correct.**
ground_truth: For the piecewise function to be continuous, the cases must "meet" at $2$ and $-2$. For example, $ax+3$ and $x-5$ must be equal when $x=2$. This implies $a(2)+3=2-5$, which we solve to get $2a=-6 \Rightarrow a=-3$. Similarly, $x-5$ and $2x-b$ must be equal when $x=-2$. Substituting, we get $-2-5=2(-2)-b$, which implies $b=3$. So $a+b=-3+3=\boxed{0}$.
